# Overview

Due to limitations to the RPi GPIO, it has been decided to use an Arduino (here called Arduino proxy) for general pin input/output operations. This document gives an overview of how the RPi and Arduino communicate together.

# Communication

## Communication Stack

The communication stack consists of a few components all working together to reliably send messages between the two devices.

First, we use serial for the physical link.

Second, we need an actual format to send the messages across. For simplicity and flexibility purposes, [Protocol Buffers](https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers) is used.

Finally, because serial only send streams of bytes, we need to be able to combine those bytes into packets. For this, we use [COBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consistent_Overhead_Byte_Stuffing) to provide packet framing. This allows to use the 0x0 byte to separate each of the packets.

All together, here is how the communication stack looks:
```diagram

```



Or, another way to look at it:
```diagram

```


## Protobuf Messages

Please look at [the repo](https://github.com/uorocketry/protobuf-definitions) for the latest Protobuf definitions. This section will simply go over the major aspects of the messages.

### ArduinoIn

The `ArduinoIn` message encapsulates any messages sent from the RPi to the Arduino. The various message types that can be sent include `ServoInit`, `ServoControl`, `Reset`, etc.

### ArduinoOut

The `ArduinoOut` message encapsulates any messages sent from the Arduino to the RPi. This is used to transmit various states back to the RPi, along with event and error messages.

### Event and Error Messages

To minimize the Arduino binary size and minimize the amount of data sent over the wire, strings are not used for logging. Instead, two Protobuf messages are used: `EventMessage` and `ErrorMessage`.

An `EventMessage` is used to signal some event happened, such as a servo being initialized, a reset just happened, etc. The specific event is represented by the `EventTypes` Protobuf enum, and only limited information can be sent along with the event.

`ErrorMessage` is similar to `EventMessage`, but should instead be used for unforeseen events, things that require immediate attention.

# Arduino Proxy
https://github.com/uorocketry/arduino-io-proxy

The Arduino Proxy itself is pretty simple. The file structure tries to keep related things together, like servo control in the `servoMessage.cpp` file, digital control in `digitalMessage.cpp`, etc.

For logging, `sendEventMessage` and `sendErrorMessage` should be used.

# Rocket-Code

Communication with the Arduino Proxy is done in the `ArduinoProxy` class. This class is initialized by the interface and is a singleton. `DigitalOutput` and `PwmOutput` can be configured to use `ArduinoProxy` for GPIO.
